She added: &ldquoWe have to do all of those things.Mr Halligan hit back at the &ldquoscare story and said &ldquono we don&rsquot before reminding the Labour MP that Britain will automatically fall under WTO rules in the event of a no deal Brexit.The heated debate was sparked from comments made by supermarket bosses who have claimed that a no deal Brexit would force them to hike the prices of food by a huge 12 percent.Brexit news: Liam Halligan said Britain will be free of huge EU tariffs under a no deal Brexit (Image: ITV&bullCORE Politics)Senior executives from some of the biggest supermarket giants in the UK made the prediction to the government during a set of briefings on the impact of food bills should Britain leave the EU with a no-deal Brexit.They warned the biggest tariffs on imports from the bloc could be cheese, which could rocket by 44 percent, followed by beef, up 40 percent, and chicken, up by 22 percent.One leading supermarket chairman warned food imported from the EU would be hit with an average tariff of 22 percent.A supermarket chairman said: &ldquoIt&rsquos complete nonsense that Brexit supporters say we could, without any damage, go to WTO most favoured nation tariffs.&ldquoIt&rsquos dreadful. There will be hold-ups at the border and that will make it impossible to take things out of the ground in Spain this morning and get them onto the shelves in two days&rsquo time.He added: &ldquoThis is so serious we&rsquore talking about civil unrest on the streets. Within two weeks of no deal this will become a very different country.Another chairman said that in the event of no deal there would be &ldquoa material increase in food prices.He added: &ldquoFinally some ministers seem to be waking up to that.But Iceland founder Malcolm Walker hit back and said the &ldquoscaremongering about stockpiling food is &ldquoall b*******.

title: ross edgley swimathon world record
story: Ross is planning to swim 2,000 miles (Image: Harvey Gibson  Red Bull Content Pool)SEVENTY FOUR days ago endurance athlete and adventurer Ross Edgley, 32, lowered himself into Margate harbour in Kent and started swimming west.Fuelled by a remarkable 15,000 calories per day (the average calorie intake for a male is 2,500) he is aiming to become the first person to swim around the entire British mainland and hopes to complete the epic 2,000-mile swim by late September when he will reap- pear in Margate harbour &ndash and all without setting a foot on dry land.The fitness writer and former bodybuilder is still swimming for up to 12 hours a day, every day, only pausing to sleep on his support boat.And today, at approximately 2pm and half way into his epic challenge, he will set a new world record for the longest sea swim.As his muscular shoulders help power him around the Inner Hebrides and through some of the coldest water in the British Isles, Ross will smash Benoit Lecomte&rsquos 1998 record of 73 days spent swimming across the Atlantic Ocean &ndash and he&rsquos still got weeks to go before he will complete his challenge.It&rsquos all part of his bid to raise awareness of the RNLI&rsquos Respect The Water campaign.                London Marathon 2019 ballot: How to apply for next year&rsquos marathon?                H2OMG! Can this man swim around Britain?&ldquoThe record is the cherry on top, says Ross, from Grantham in Lincolnshire, during a break on his support boat off the coast of Skye.&ldquoI set out to swim around Great Britain but to be able to say &lsquoYou know where the longest sea swim was done? Great Britain&rsquo. Well that&rsquos an added bonus.As well as the beauty of swimming alongside dolphins and even a Minke whale which followed him for a while in the Bristol Channel, Ross has had to cope with a disintegrating tongue due to &ldquosalt mouth, the danger of submerged rocks, fiendish tides and the toughest waves our nation can muster.There have been basking sharks, wetsuit chafing and the pain of relentless jellyfish stings to his face while swimming up to 31 nautical miles a day &ndash something he achieved in the Irish Sea when he got caught in an extreme tide.&ldquoThe armoured fortified beard is my secret weapon, he laughs as he considers his new facial hair.&ldquoThe jellyfish ricochet off it. I&rsquove also developed really good peripheral vision to identify them and give them a wide berth when I can. And to cope with salt tongue, which meant bits of my tongue were literally falling off, I now lubricate my mouth with coconut oil.Holidays 2018: From Mauritius to the Males, be in awe of some of the most beautiful swimming pools revealed by Emirates Holidays.                    PR1 of 11The most incredible swimming pools in the world revealed by Emirates Holidays&ldquoI&rsquove also been slammed by wind and waves. It&rsquos not all sunshine and dolphins. But never once, even when my tongue was falling apart and I&rsquove been stung in the face so often I&rsquom feeling dizzy from the toxins, have I thought I was going to quit.Not so surprising when you consider that Ross kicked off 2018 by completing a marathon while dragging a Mini Cooper behind him for the entire course.In 2016 he achieved the world&rsquos longest rope climb by scaling a rope repeatedly until reaching the equivalent height of Mount Everest &ndash 8,848 metres &ndash in less than 24 hours (working his way through two pairs of shoes and 10 pairs of gloves in the process).&ldquoThe mindset you choose is what makes it easier and more enjoyable, he declares. &ldquoAnd the support of the amazing team on the boat.This includes his girlfriend of five years Hester Sabery, 27, who joins the boat most weekends.&ldquoIt&rsquos really nice to have that sense of home, Ross says. &ldquoAnd Hester can treat wounds that others probably wouldn&rsquot want to treat. She&rsquos like, &lsquoBabe, like look at your feet, they are horrible&rsquo and put socks on.Ross is hoping to set a new world record (Image: Leo FrancisRed Bull Content Pool)Today, having taken a break to celebrate his record-breaking triumph, this strongman will climb back into the water after boosting his energy with a protein shake and contend once again with powerful waves, and being lost in his own thoughts by day and what he calls the &ldquosensory deprivation of swimming blind during night swims.&ldquoSometimes I beatbox to pass the time. Other times I think about what I&rsquom going to eat next, he says of his serious banana habit fuelled by his on-board nutritionist. In longer breaks he might read from Meditations by philosopher Marcus Aurelius.&ldquoSwimming magnifies your feelings, whether positive or negative. I try to keep them positive. Support has also come from more unusual sources.&ldquoI love the Scottish people, they even come bearing food, says the relentlessly upbeat Ross of one local mermaid keen to help him on his way.&ldquoIona, a wild swimmer, swam out to me doing breast stroke and balancing a piping hot cake on her head. She had been following my journey and baked me a cake specially.&ldquoAnd in Sidmouth someone left Devonshire fudge on the end of the boat in the middle of the night and a note saying &lsquogood luck with the swim&rsquo. The scenery has been amazing but the people have made this special.He has also put on weight in a bid to keep warm in the eye-wateringly cold temperatures. &ldquoI have now got this tummy to store body fat.It means I&rsquom better at cuddling but also at staying warm.But Ross, who learnt to swim at the age of six, denies that his swimming style is anything to write home about.&ldquoI&rsquom like a whale, not pretty at all. With endurance swimming I barely kick my legs &ndash it&rsquos 90 per cent arms because kicking only accounts for about 10 per cent propulsion so I&rsquom more efficient if I don&rsquot use them. I look like I&rsquom rolling on my tummy having eaten a large Christmas lunch.A former member of the British water polo squad who went on to co-found The Protein Works, a sports nutrition company, Ross&rsquos interest in endurance began in November 2016 when he attempted a triathlon with a tree on his back &ndash the &ldquotree-athlon as he calls it.Ross completed a trialathon carrying a log (Image: Ross Edgley's official Instagram page)&ldquoOn the bike and run stages I was awful but on the swim I was quite quick and I ended up overtaking people.&ldquoSome friends said, &lsquoYou&rsquore clearly quite good at that &ndash why don&rsquot you just do the swim?&rsquo Before I knew it I was swimming the Caribbean with a tree on my back.&ldquoPulling a 1.4 tonne car for 26.2 miles raised lots of money for charity and after that a few hours in the weights room no longer seemed as fun. So I bought a rope. Found a tree. Then put a date in the diary.And he started his bizarre 24-hour endurance climb which saw him scale the 10-metre rope nearly 900 times before stopping. But he admits that his latest extreme stunt &ldquomakes the others look like a warm-up.The idea for the Great British Swim was sparked partly by GB Row, the &lsquoworld&rsquos toughest&rsquo rowing race which circumnavigates the UK and is notorious because of the tides, the currents and the unpredictability of the coast- line around Britain.&ldquoI thought, &lsquoIf that&rsquos the toughest rowing race, why don&rsquot I enter it, just without a boat.&rsquo People have run around Great Britain, cycled around it and rowed around it. No one has swum around it. It seemed like it just needed doing, he adds, before getting back in the chilly Scottish waters.

purity of perfection.&ldquoIn politics, &lsquoperfection&rsquo does not exist, it is the siren song calling us on to the rocks.It is understood the EU&rsquos chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, and the title: Brexit news latest uk Andrea Jenkyns Chequers deal
story: Ms Jenkyns, who quit her position as a ministerial aide earlier this year so she could &ldquofight for Brexit, said that the Prime Minister&rsquos Chequers deal did not equate to a meaningful Brexit and that &lsquono deal&rsquo and abiding by WTO rules would be preferable to the current Chequers plan.&nbspThe MP for Morley and Outwood said she received &ldquohundreds of emails and letters a week from constituents and people across the country telling her that &ldquoChequers does not mean Brexit.She continued: &ldquoThe UK must be free to seize all opportunities that Brexit can provide and that means leaving the Single Market and taking back control of our money, leaving the jurisdiction of the EU courts to take back control of our laws and leaving the Customs Union to be free to make free trade deals across the world with historic allies such as Australia, New Zealand, USA and Canada and also new emerging economies.&ldquoThese are things I wrote to the Prime Minister about back in July, along with 33 other MPs. We need to believe in Britain. We need to &lsquochuck Chequers&rsquo. #StandUp4Brexit. God save the Queen!&nbspIn July, Ms Jenkyns was a signatory to a letter delivered to Prime Minister Theresa May which urged her to &ldquoget tough in your negotiations with the European Union.&nbspThe letter said: &ldquoWe are looking to you to demonstrate courage and leadership in the face of those who seek to undermine the express wish of the British people in the 2016 referendum.&ldquoOur departure must be absolute. We must not remain entangled with the EU&rsquos institutions if this restricts our ability to exercise our sovereignty as an independent nation.&ldquoAnything less will be a weakening of our democracy. Britain must stand firm.&nbspIn July,&nbspMs Jenkyns also called for a &ldquonew Prime Minister saying that she &ldquowould like to see a Brexiteer in place.&nbsp&ldquoSomebody who really believes in the cause and bang that drum and to provide a positive vision really. I feel that is, unfortunately,&nbsplacking at the moment.&ldquoOn the&nbspbackbenches,&nbspit is very frustrating, I have always been a loyal Conservative. I have never voted against the Government, but there&nbspare&nbspan increasing number of us that are getting frustrated. And we feel that we are not delivering Brexit.Brexit News Andrea Jenkyns says a no deal Brexit is perferable to May's Chequers deal  (Image: BBC Parliament &bull StandUp4Brexit)The Prime Minister was forced to strengthen her Brexit negotiation offer to the EU following the threat of a revolt from eurosceptic MPs.Mrs May accepted four amendments tabled by Tory backbenchers to her Customs Bill, with Downing Street aides claiming the changes were &ldquoconsistent with her Brexit plans.The Prime Minister avoided a defeat in the House of Commons by just three votes, over the European Research Group&rsquos trickiest amendment.The Eurosceptic Conservative MPs' new clause 36, to prevent the UK collecting tariffs on behalf of the EU unless the EU agrees to collect them for the UK, was approved by 305 votes to 302, majority three.

title: Brexit news UK EU Ireland Germany Italy Belgium France no deal latest
story: EU members could end up shelling out over &pound500billion as they prepare for trade tariffs and extra costs associated with Britain leaving the bloc without a withdrawal agreement, according to a bombshell report.According to work carried out by Professor Patrick Minford, a former adviser to Margaret Thatcher and chairman of Economists for Free Trade, the EU would end up forking out &pound433 billion in trade tariffs on a WTO deal.Also EU countries would suffer a 1.5 percent drop in national income in the event of a no deal, according to a separate study by the International Monetary Fund.The EU&rsquos lost economic output would cost the bloc around cost an estimated &pound189bn, leaving member states&rsquo industries potentially devastated.Ireland, Italy, France, Belgium and Germany would be amongst the EU&rsquos biggest losers. Here&rsquos how they could be hit.                Economist warns 'EU is petrified' of UK making a success of BrexitIrelandDublin would suffer a massive four percent hit to its GDP as a result of a no deal Brexit &ndash the worst of any EU member.The IMF predicts because of the highly integrated nature of the Irish and the UK&rsquos economies, Ireland could face significant consequences as a result.The Republic of Ireland relies heavily on cross-border trade with Northern Ireland. In 2016, Northern Ireland exported around &pound4 billion worth of goods and services to the south.The Republic exported roughly &pound1.3 billion of goods in the same year, according to their own figures.Brexit news: Germany and France amongst countries who could be hit by no-deal orce (Image: )FranceParis&rsquo &pound4 billion trade surplus with Britain would be put at significant risk if no withdrawal deal is reached.Gerald Darmanian, a French finance minister, said a no-deal Brexit would a &ldquodisaster for the flow of goods between Britain and the Continent.France is also fuming after European Commission planning decided to exclude French ports from new shipping routes between Ireland and the Continent.This means Paris&rsquo coastal ports could lose on on billions of EU funding to help increase their capacity after Brexit.                &lsquoI GUARANTEE it!&rsquo City expert bets &pound3.6BN on UK negotiating free trade                'UNACCEPTABLE' French FURY over EU plan to EXCLUDE French ports GermanyBerlin currently enjoys trade deals with Britain that are worth &pound61 billion, which the Federation of German Industry warns are at risk in the event of a no deal.The BDI is worried about increased friction in trade with Britain after Brexit. The UK is the second-biggest export market for German car manufacturers.Customs duties of &pound2 billion a year would be added to the cost of German cars bought by British consumers under a no-deal Brexit.Last year, 950,000 cars made by Volkswagen, BMW and Mercedes-Benz were registered in the UK as part of the &pound20 billion worth of German cars that were imported.Dominic Raab and Michel Barnier are working to strike a deal but EU members fear the worst (Image: )BelgiumA no-deal Brexit will hurt the Belgian economy seriously, according to shock warnings from its finance minister Johan Van Overtveldt.The country will lose around 42,000 in the Flanders region alone as havoc is wreaked across the small nation.Mr Van Overtveldt said: Belgium is the fourth exporter, in nominal amounts, into the UK, on a par with France which is a much bigger country. And so, if Brexit goes the wrong way, in terms of the hard Brexit, it will hurt the Belgian economy seriously.We&rsquore talking about thousands and thousands of jobs depending on the business done with the UK.ItalyRome could have to contribute an extra &pound900 million a year into Brussels' budget coffers in order to make up the shortfall left by Brexit.The country's farmers are also concerned that any restriction in free trade between the Italy and the UK would devastate their industry.Roberto Moncalvo, president of Italian farming union Coldiretti said the UK&rsquos exit from the EU in March 2019 would &ldquoweaken Italy&rsquos farming industry and export trade.He warned Italian agriculture &ldquocan&rsquot pay the price of Brexit.They fear an estimated cut of &euro2.7billion (&pound2.3billion) to the budget of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), something which could heavily impact 800,000 Italian farms.

title: independence day 2018 pakistan why is Independence Day on August 14 how celebrated
story: Pakistan Independence Day: People of Pakistan celebrate their independence from the British Raj (Image: )Fireworks and celebrations started as the clock struck midnight all across Pakistan, as the nation celebrates its independence following the end of the British Raj in 1947.The British Raj was the rule by the British Crown in the Indian subcontinent between 1858 and 1947.In 1946, the British Labour government led by Clement Attlee realised it did not have the support to keep controlling British India, of which Pakistan was a part of.After World War II, Britain did not have the mandate at home, nor the reliability of the British Indian Army to keep power in restless British India.                Top 10 facts about Pakistan                Pakistan: Imran Khan could break election pledgeIndia acted rebellious towards Britain&rsquos native forces, so the government decided to end the British rule.In 1947, Muhammad Ali Jinnah, leader of the All-India Muslim League started a movement which would later lead to the formal establishment of Pakistan and declaration of its sovereignty.The Indian Independence Act 1947 confirmed the British Raj would grant independence to the Dominion of Pakistan, which compromised West and East Pakistan.East Pakistan is today Bangladesh.Pakistan&rsquos Independence Day is marked on August 14, as the transfer of power took place on the midnight of August 14 and 15, 1947.India celebrates their Independence Day on August 15.Pakistan Independence Day: Fireworks and celebrations started as the clock struck midnight (Image: )How is Pakistan Independence Day celebrated?The main celebration takes place in Islamabad, the capital of Pakistan.The Independence Day event will be hosted at the Islamabad Convention Centre, and caretaker Prime Minister Nasirul Mulk, President Mamnoon Hussain and other key personalities will be in attendance.For the people of Pakistan flag-raising ceremonies, cultural events, patriotic songs and parades are a big part of their day.                UK to DOUBLE controversial foreign aid to &pound300 MILLION in cash by 2025                Imran Khan latest: Ex-cricketer to be named Pakistan's prime ministerPakistan Independence Day: The people of Pakistan show their national pride (Image: )They also purchase national flags, badges, shirts to show their national pride.The nation&rsquos flag is also hoisted at state-official buildings such as the Pakistani Parliament.This year the flag will be hoisted by President Mamnoon Hussain.Leaders will then have live televised speeches, by both the President and the Prime Minister.Pakistan Independence Day: The main celebrations take place in Islamabad (Image: )Newly elected Prime Minister-to-be Imran Khan posted an optimistic message to the people on Twitter, stating Pakistan is to become a &ldquogreat nation.&ldquoOn this Independence Day I am filled with the greatest optimism.&ldquoDespite our grave economic crisis, due to corruption and cronyism, I know if we are united in our resolve, we will rise to the challenge &amp Pak will become the great nation envisaged by our Quaid &amp Iqbal.

title: independence day 2018 how old is Pakistan why Pakisten before India independence day
story: Crowds gather, wave the country's flag and sing national songs (Image: EPA)Pakistan&rsquos Independence Day is celebrated on August 14 and commemorates the day Pakistan was declared a sovereign nation after the end of the British Raj.&nbspThis was a result of the Pakistan Movement, which had pushed for an independent Muslim state to the north-west of India.&nbspThe Indian Independence Act was brought about in 1947, which saw the British Raj grant independence to the Dominion of Pakistan (modern-day Pakistan) and East Pakistan (Bangladesh).The British Raj was the British run system of governance in India - which lasted from 1858 to 1947.                Pakistan: Imran Khan could break election pledge                Independence Day 2018 Pakistan: Why is Independence Day on August 1...Pakistan's independence was campaigned for by the All-India Muslim League under the leadership of Muhammad Ali Jinnah.&nbspPakistan&rsquos Independence Day is celebrated with special prayers in mosques - centred around peace and security of the country.&nbspStarting at the beginning of August, fairs, stalls and shops pop up throughout the country to sell national flags, bunting, badges, banners and other celebratory merchandise.&nbspThere is also a flag hoisting ceremony held at the Presidential and Parliamentary buildings in Pakistan's capital, Islamabad, followed by television addresses by the country&rsquos leaders.&nbspCelebrities and political leaders speak at rallies and events, praising national heroes and leading celebrations.&nbspParades, patriotic songs and award ceremonies are also held throughout Pakistan.&nbspA 21-gun salute will also take place in Islamabad.How old is Pakistan?                Imran Khan: Pakistan leader vows to take back &lsquoLOOTED&rsquo money in UK                 Imran Khan latest: Ex-cricketer to be named Pakistan's prime ministerPakistan&rsquos independence was declared in 1947, announced at midnight on the night between August 14 and 15.This united the eastern and northwestern regions of what was known as British India.&nbspPakistan is 71-years-old, with Prime Minister Clement Attlee announcing in February of 1947 that the British Government would grant full self-governance to British India, and the act being passed in August 1947.This is the 72nd independence day for Pakistan, and prime minister-in-waiting Imran Khan tweeted to remind citizens of the origins of the day - and two founders Muhammad Ali Jinnah and Muhammad Iqbal.A young girl has had her nails painted with the national flag (Image: EPA)Khan tweeted: &ldquoOn this Independence Day I am filled with the greatest optimism.&nbspDespite our grave economic crises, due to corruption and cronyism, I know if we are united in our resolve, we will rise to the challenge and Pakistan will become the great nation envisaged by our Quaid &amp Iqbal.&nbspWhy is Pakistan&rsquos Independence Day before India&rsquos?Both Pakistan and India were granted independence in 1947, however, celebrate their independence days on separate days.&nbspThe national flag is everywhere on independence day on nails, faces, buildings, cars and more (Image: EPA)The two self-governing countries came into existence at midnight on August 15 1947, yet Pakistan celebrate this a day earlier.The reason for Pakistan celebrating their independence day on August 14, and India theirs on August 15 is due to the wish of the last British Viceroy - Lord Mountbatten of Burma - to attend both initial independence ceremonies in 1947.&nbspThe ceremonies for transfer of power took place on August 14, 1947, for Pakistan and August 15, 1947, for India.

title: affray ben stokes plea sentence
story: Here we explain exactly what affray is and how long you could be sent to prison for if youre found guilty.Affray is an offence that involves unlawful fighting or a display of force by at least one person against one or more people.It is also the threat of violence, which is more than just verbal.It is a common law offence and is triable by a judge and jury.Affray may also be committed in private places as well as public areas.England cricket ace Ben Stokes was charged with affray following a brawl outside a Bristol nightclub.The England all-rounder was allegedly involved in the scuffle in September 2017.Stokes, 27, was charged alongside two other men and appeared for his preliminary hearing at Bristol Magistrates Court on February 13, 2018, to plead not guilty.On the morning of August 6, 2018, the cricketer appeared at Bristol Crown Court.The trial is expected to draw to a close on  August 13 with closing arguments before the jury decides their verdict.Affray is taken seriously in the British courts.The maximum penalty for the offence is three years in prison.The defendant can also be fined an unlimited amount.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: expected better from brad pitt and angelina jolie
story: Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie were the caring, sharing, rainbow family that was going to last for ever and ever.Somewhere down the line this relationship buckled, fractured and has now imploded into a bitter legal fight that boiled over in court this week.I expected better of these two.Despite the fact Brad dumped his girl-next-door first wife, Jennifer Aniston, for his sexy, smouldering Mr &amp Mrs Smith co-star Angelina in 2005, I really thought “Brangelina” would go the distance.In the unlikely event the fairy-tale romance turned sour, I believed they would handle the whole thing with dignity and respect for one another.After all, they have six children together and seemed the kind of parents, who would not want to drag their kids through a messy divorce case or custody battle. Well, I was wrong about the messy divorce.Bam! This week Angelina claimed that Brad wasn’t paying her enough child support.Kapow! He hit back that he has coughed up over £7million since they first split over 18 months ago.Sock! Angelina then put the boot in by saying that most of the money was just a loan that she’s having to pay back with interest.Wham! He claims she wants to manipulate the media into branding him a deadbeat dad.It once again proves that no one knows what’s going on inside someone else’s marriage.It might look perfect bliss on the outside, but we have no idea what tense battles are being fought on a daily basis behind closed doors.Despite us all being spoon-fed stories of their perfect relationship over the years, and shown photos of their wedding when the children drew pictures on Angelina’s beautiful white dress, it appears that this relationship has been on the rocks for quite some time.Brad’s friends claim she is fired up with anger over the custody battle and doesn’t want the children to have any sort of relationship with their father.They have slammed her for going public instead of having the divorce hammered out in front of a private judge.Her friends counterclaim that he drank too much and was “rough” with one of the children, thought to be Maddox, the eldest, while they were on a private plane.He was cleared of any wrongdoing, but mud sticks and this was highly damaging as well as deeply distressing for Brad.These two extremely gifted, pampered, beautiful people might have met on a movie set and become infatuated with each other, but this is not a film.This is real life and there are six bewildered youngsters caught up in the eye of the storm.There’s the aforementioned Maddox, 17, then Pax, 14, Zahara, 13, Shiloh, 12, and ten-year-old twins Vivienne and Knox.Shiloh and the twins are the biological children of Brad and Angelina, but they have all been brought up to think of themselves as full brothers and sisters, and just one big family.So it must now be extremely unsettling for them to see all the news reports about custody fights and money squabbles, and to have witnessed friends of their parents forced into taking sides.I have no idea whether the children witnessed any arguments or screaming matches between their parents, but there surely must have been an uncomfortable atmosphere at home in the months before the split.The poor, wee children actually have their own psychiatrists that Brad’s friends claim he pays for.And they have round-the-clock bodyguards available.As with so many splits, money has reared its ugly head, and despite their enormous wealth (it’s estimated that Brad is worth £202million and that Angelina has a personal fortune of £125million) it would appear that it’s all coming down to cold, hard cash.We are a long, long way from the heady Brangelina days when they were the world’s sexiest couple and couldn’t keep their hands off each other.Sadly, most white-hot affairs tend to fizzle out when domesticity kicks in and you need to change nappies and wipe snot from little faces.Even with a team of nannies, six children running around is probably one of the biggest passion killers of all time.So, it’s a real shame that Brad and Angelina couldn’t make it work, but sadder still that their dirty washing is being aired for all the world to see.But theirs is not the only love story to turn rancid . . .ROMEO and Juliet ended in tragedy at the end of Gone With The Wind, Rhett tells Scarlett that he doesn’t give a damn about her reality TV romances rarely last beyond the first glossy magazine spread.I’M not in the least bit surprised that doctors don’t trust us to tell the truth when it comes to how much booze we guzzle.Apparently they nod wisely when we solemnly declare that we have but one small sherry on a Sunday night while watching Songs of Praise, and then they simply double whatever we say or put down a number that seems most likely.New info this week says that just 40 per cent of patients tell the truth to their GPs when it comes to how much they drink every week.Frankly, I’m astonished the figure is that high.Most of us play down our booze intake and exaggerate the amount of exercise we do, but even as we are telling such huge porkies, we all know in our hearts that our doctors aren’t the least bit fooled.We want them to think we are model citizens and that our bodies are temples, but in the long run we need to tell the truth so we can get a proper diagnosis and treatment.And always bear in mind you can’t kid a kidder.There are lots of doctors who overindulge and they know all the tricks and cover-ups.IT’S the final episode of The Handmaid’s Tale tomorrow night, and I will be watching from behind the sofa to find out the fate of our heroine June.She inhabits a world where women have no rights, and handmaids are ritually raped, mutilated and even killed.It’s not easy viewing, but Elisabeth Moss has been mesmerising throughout as June, whose first child was ripped from her arms, and whose newborn baby was also taken away from her.I’m bracing myself for an emotional rollercoaster and Miss Moss should clear her sideboard for a slew of awards.The Handmaid’s Tale, Sunday, Channel 4, 9pm.WHAT sad news to discover that Margot Kidder, who shone so very brightly as the feisty and fiercely intelligent Lois Lane in the original Superman movies, died by suicide.Margot’s death happened back in May, but it was revealed this week that she died as a rfesult of a “self-inflicted drug and alcohol overdose”.The 69-year-old suffered from depression and other mental health issues, which became worse after a car accident in 1990 left her wheelchair-bound for almost two years and facing mounting debts.She had a very tough time but she tried hard to sort out her life and cope with her illness.We should remember her in her heyday.I loved the fact she wasn’t a conventional glamour puss at a time when any actress playing the “love interest” in an action movie was usually a busty blonde doing little more than squeaking and waiting to be rescued.Lois Lane was a kick-ass reporter who adored Superman but also made fun of him during four movies between 1978 and 1987.Those films had real heart and soul and – if you ignore the rather wobbly special effects – are far more entertaining than many of the over-long, over-loud and rather self-important superhero movies of today.I’M no fan of his, but I don’t think Boris Johnson should be forced to apologise for likening woman who wear burkas to letter boxes.It’s his opinion.You very well might disagree, but getting him to say sorry won’t make him stop thinking such thoughts.He will just stop writing and uttering that particular view in public and instead will voice it in private.And that, in my opinion, is far more dangerous.GOT a story? RING The Sun on 0207 782 4104 or WHATSAPP on 07423720250 or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady column self harm
story: New research reveals that the number of girls aged 13 to 16 reporting self-harm to GPs has increased by 68 per cent over just three years.It’s a staggering rise — and that is just the reported cases.Given that self-harm tends to be a solitary pursuit, I think it’s realistic to assume that there are many, many more unreported cases.Self-harm among young people aged ten to 19 is three times more common among girls than boys. Bearing in mind that those who self-harm are at much greater risk of suicide, this is not a problem to be taken lightly.For some young people the act of cutting, or otherwise inflicting pain on themselves, is a way of relieving — albeit temporarily — mental pain and torment by converting it into something more visible and tangible.It’s a way of relieving tension and an attempt to clarify a confusing mental swirl into something that is easier to understand in its simplicity. It’s also a way of punishing yourself.So why the sudden, huge, increase in girls taking this path?Psychiatrists commenting on the research blamed a combination of academic stresses and body-image issues triggered by the use of social media.There’s no doubt that social media, which barely existed ten years ago, has, along with all the good stuff, brought with it a whole new set of pressures.Women’s appearances have always been scrutinised, but that unique equation of the selfie generation plus Photoshop plus the sheer variety of ways to propel your image out into the world has created a series of impossible standards.It’s also created a whole generation that is convinced that everything is going brilliantly for everyone else.When teenagers look at their friend’s social media feeds they see apparently perfect lives, bodies, homes and jobs.And then they feel inadequate.There are other pressures: Pressure to do well in exams have amazing friendships and be brilliantly successful. And, for some people, the relief to those pressures is to hurt themselves, which is surely the saddest and one of the most difficult problems any parent can deal with.After all, it’s our natural instinct to protect our children from harm. But what can we do when the harm comes from within themselves?All teenage kids have intensely difficult phases. And the pressures at school can feel unbearable.If someone doesn’t like you, it feels like the end of the world. If you fail an exam you can feel doomed to failure. School feels like it will never end.Our job is to try to help our children get perspective.Despite the downsides of excessive social media being well documented, it seems that most young people would rather end up with mental health problems than give it up. So maybe they need a helping hand.We need to talk more to our kids about the reality of social media — and limit their time on it.And we need to coax them out of their screen-sized comfort zone.One of the best things kids can do is some volunteering.That way they can meet kids from different backgrounds and people with real problems — such as children born with disabilities who are still making the most of their life.Sport is also brilliant for getting kids to enjoy being part of something bigger than their bedroom, and for celebrating their bodies for what they can do rather than what they look like.The big question is, how can we get them to talk about their feelings, instead of engraving them into their skin until they draw blood?Be kind, patient but determined and, most importantly, we need to talk to our children, ask them how they are feeling — and listen to the answers without judgment.If they won’t talk to you, find someone else they can talk to, either a family friend or even a counsellor if you’re worried about self-harm.But the Government also needs to invest more money into care.Less than one per cent of the NHS budget is spent on children’s mental health, and most of that is on acute care rather than preventative or early intervention services.That needs to change.Most of all, we need to accept that there is a problem and find ways to address it. Because if we don’t, things are going to get much, much worse.SURELY only those with the hardest of hearts could complain about the affection shown by Zara and Mike Tindall, who are frequently photographed kissing, hugging and looking generally happy and totally loved-up.Given they have survived challenging personal losses and have two young children, it’s pretty much a miracle they are so happy.How could anyone wish them anything but well?DID you see the Kardashian and Jenner sisters at Kylie Jenner’s 21st birthday party?What is most striking – other than them all being drop-dead gorgeous, of course – is that they each have totally different body types.I guess what they DO have in common is an unlimited budget for personal trainers and chefs . . . plus the fact that looking this good is their full-time job.His crime was horrific and he deserved to be dealt with.His punishment was to be beheaded and his body crucified and displayed in Mecca.A beheading and crucifixion in this century?There are instances when I do believe that the death penalty is just, but this method is just barbaric.THE latest advice from fertility specialists to women who want to “delay motherhood” is for them to freeze their eggs in their early twenties.At the moment, the vast majority of women who go through the procedure do so in their late thirties – by which time they have little chance of success. But who is going to freeze their eggs in their twenties?I was fortunate to meet the right man in my twenties – and had children once I was married because I wanted to have a family.But plenty of women don’t meet the right partner that early in life, or simply don’t want to have children until they are older.One reason for that is that they want to have a career – and they know babies can seriously damage their chances of promotion or even a pay rise.But the solution is not for women to freeze their eggs.The real solution is a shift in the division of labour between mothers and fathers.So long as the children are not the sole responsibility of just one person in the family, things can work well.If both partners are equally involved, nobody has to totally compromise their life and put their career on hold.As things stand, no wonder women are putting off motherhood. But if more men pulled their weight, maybe women wouldn’t have to worry about freezing their eggs.WHEN you look at photos of the 200 travellers who have descended on the village of Long Ditton in Surrey, you can see why local police sparked fury by telling residents who want to evict them to have empathy instead.The police force tweeted: “Consider for a second how upsetting it would be, being uprooted every few days.”But the photos show piles of rubbish and damaged property.In one, a child is sitting on an adult’s lap while he drives a car around the village green. And I dread to think about the specifics of the toilet situation.What is needed is not empathy but police action.SOME high-profile, wealthy parents – such as Sting, Elton John and Simon Cowell – make a point of saying they won’t leave their fortunes to their children for fear it will ruin their lives.Location, Location, Location presenter Kirstie Allsopp has taken a different tack.She says she will leave her £16million fortune to her two sons . . . IF they get a job.I applaud the sentiment. But if you really want your children to develop a work ethic, rather than relying on inherited income, isn’t the key not to tell your kids – and the whole world – in a national newspaper?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government hiking fuel duty
story: Britain’s motorists already get a raw deal at the petrol pump, with fuel duty among the highest in the world.Why should they be hammered further to help bankroll the £20billion NHS splurge?A hike will make people poorer, take cash out of the economy and stoke inflation. Low-paid workers, who need their cars and vans for work, will be unfairly hit.So will ordinary, hard-pressed families, who already have to budget to fill up so they can take their kids to school and transport their weekly supermarket shop.In other words, it will unfairly impact the “Just About Managings” who Theresa May once claimed she would strive to protect.Philip Hammond might regard drivers as a convenient cash cow to fill the Treasury’s coffers.But he should resist clobbering them for a quick cash injection. Targeting those struggling is political cowardice.Voters won’t forgive him.ORDINARY Brits back Boris Johnson.His joke about Muslim women wearing the full black robe looking like “letterboxes” and “bank robbers” has been portrayed as an affront.But away from all the Twitter outrage, the former Foreign Secretary is in step with public opinion.Meanwhile, Jeremy Corbyn continues to shame Labour with his anti-Semitism.Of course, just as we are free to debate the burka, people are free to debate the Israel-Palestine conflict.But a politician with aspirations to run the country should not be laying wreaths for terror leaders.Corbyn believes Israel is the ultimate malevolent force, a racist imperial outpost, causing the world’s ills at the behest of America and Britain. How many traditional Labour voters today share his worldview?It is Boris, derided by his enemies as an Etonian toff, who has his finger on the nation’s pulse and understands the concerns of ordinary people.No surprise that in one poll the Tories have opened a four-point lead over Corbyn’s Labour.After a short summer break following our fantastic World Cup, it is great to have the beautiful game back.We’ve already witnessed breathtaking goals, crunching tackles and some blinding saves.And there is nowhere better to get the best football coverage than inside Britain’s favourite newspaper.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: employers now favour apprenticeships or experience over university degrees study reveals
story: Researchers who polled 1,000 decision makers found 49 per cent prefer to see experience from a relevant apprenticeship or previous position on a candidate’s CV.Just 24 per cent said they would be more likely to take on someone who had a relevant degree qualification.The study was carried out by AAT (Association of Accounting Technicians) ahead of A Level results day on Thursday August 16th.Of those who said they prioritise candidates who have relevant experience from an apprenticeship or previous job, 71 per cent said they prefer it because it shows they have demonstrated their skills in a practical setting.And 62 per cent said it indicates they have a better understanding of the world of work.Suzie Webb, AAT’s Director of Education and Development said: “Ahead of A-Level results day, we wanted to inform young people about the things employers are looking for, to help them have a clear idea of what they need to consider as they think about their careers.“Many people still think that having a university degree will be most valued by employers, but our research suggests this is not always the case.”The study also found strong communication skills, punctuality and title: instagram user pet dog washing machine followers bid
story: The disturbing video was posted to social media by Tamara Rotman, a popular Argentinian social media star.In the footage, her dog Coco can be seen inside the washing machine with her face pushed up against the door.The dog, a West Highland White Terrier, seems traumatised at being trapped inside and appears to be struggling to get out.Rotman added a survey with the question are you going to be really traumatised? next to the video.Commentators were quick to condemn the womans stupidity, with many calling for her to be punished for animal abuse.After coming under intense fire from outraged viewers posting waves of negative comments, Rotman was forced to delete her account.But just hours later, she deleted all her posts and reactivated her account, adding a single video of a happy-looking Coco playing on a green lawn.Alongside it, she posted a lengthy justification about her actions, claiming she had been misinterpreted.She added that the animal was only in the washing machine for a few seconds, which she insisted had not been switched on at any point.She wrote: I have a dog called Coco who I love with all my heart.Everyone who knows me knows that I devote my life and much much more to him.

title: girlfriend magaluf lad forgives him
story: Alun Griffiths, 27, was touching down on the Spanish resort with his mate when he got a text from partner Sarah Meah telling him tea was ready.But Sarah has revealed she wasnt angry with her boyfriend over the quick trip - and instead simply wanted him to take her away for another holiday.Speaking to the Sun Online, nurse Sarah, 36, said: I was at work while the boys were living it up in Spain and I was getting all the updates to my phone.Alun had gone out for after work drinks on Tuesday with pal Nigel Lewis when the spontaneous trip was born, with the pair travelling 30 miles to Cardiff Airport before jumping on the first flight to Magaluf.The friends arrived at 2am - heading straight for the bars before deciding to sleep on the beach when they realised they didnt have any accommodation booked.Railway site manager Alun said: My battery was dead when I woke up we were being chased off a private beach by security guards.With nowhere better to go we decided to start drinking again.Luckily we met a nice woman later in the day who used her phone to book us into a hotel so we could have a shower.We went out again that night but two days on the sesh was enough for me. Thats when I called Sarah and asked her to book me a flight home.Alun revealed that Sarah wasnt best pleased when she first wound out what happened - but had since made him promise her a trip to Amsterdam as pay back.He said: She calls me out but our rows are always in good spirit.She text back saying You are winding me up, what an idiot.But finished off telling me to have a good time.The playful dad said Sarah wasnt a nagging girlfriend, adding: But she has said Ive got to take her away now to make up for it so we are looking at a trip to Amsterdam.Hopefully this time I can give my boss a bit more notice.It was thanks to Sarah that the pair managed to get home - booking the pair the first flight back.Sarah said: The best part is that I had to rescue the boys and get them a flight home when theyd had enough.People have messaged me saying Im a mug for forgiving him but there was no fall out.Its all been a big laugh and Im just glad he was safe and they stuck together even if they did go a bit too wild.The couple have been best mates for nearly three years and only recently took their relationship to the next level.They have now been seeing each other for 8 weeks and live around the corner from each other on the Gurnos estate in Merthyr Tydfil, South Wales.Dad-of-four Alun said: We love the banter, its one of the reasons we are great together. We are mates first. Its great she can take a joke and accepts my wild ways.

title: pm faces revolt rail fare hikes
story: Livid backbenchers said a “fare freeze” was the minimum the Government should do for passengers who have suffered on Southern and Northern Rail this year.Conservative backbencher Tim Loughton said a rumoured 3.5 per cent ticket price increase would “go beyond adding insult to injury”.He told The Sun: “A fare rise would be absolutely outrageous. In any other customer facing industry we’d be looking at proper refunds.”And Treasury aide Chris Philp insisted Transport Secretary Chris Grayling had to deliver on plans announced in June to give commuters on Southern a month’s worth of compensation.He said: “No one who has suffered should be paying more next year. People have paid for a service and it’s not been received.”Labour demanded a fare freeze on Sunday – and called for a windfall tax on train operators.Official inflation figures tomorrow are due to show retail prices rose by 3.5 per cent in July. The July figure is taken as the basis for annual fare hikes in January.A 3.5 per cent rise would push up season tickets for between London and Ashford by £188 to £5,567, London and Southampton by £200 to £5,902. A season ticket from Macclesfield to Manchester on troubled Northern Rail would also rise by £90 to £2,663.The hikes come after a summer marked by timetabling chaos and cancelled services across the country.Southern has warned passengers this week they face 34 days of disruption on the Brighton to London mainline from September due to “improvement” works. Fares across the UK have soared by 40 per cent over the past decade.The Department for Transport yesterday said that while further hikes were “unwelcome” they were essential to funding work on the railways. But Tories have urged the Government to follow ex-Chancellor George Osborne – who capped regulated rail fares in 2011.Insiders argue that unions must share part of the blame for soaring ticket prices as around 25p in every £1 spent goes on wages. Labour’s former Transport Secretary Andrew Adonis said customer dissatisfaction was running at levels that would “shame” the likes of major supermarkets.He stormed: “Watchdogs Which? say that one in five rail passengers are dissatisfied with their last journey. Imagine that was a supermarket, with one in five dissatisfied with the last food they bought. Passengers shouldn’t be expected to pay more for worse.”After a disastrous year, there is no other industry that would turn round and ask customers for even more.The failure of the Government to take responsibility, blaming unions or claiming the cash is for “investment”, is simply not good enough. It’s the same as last year’s excuse.It is time for a radical overhaul — but that does not mean nationalisation. Far from it. Our railways need MORE private sector involvement.The hybrid system we have, in which private operators rely on publicly owned tracks and have their fares regulated by government, has led us into the worst of both worlds.Transport supremo Chris Grayling needs to take on the unions once and for all. And he needs to introduce real competition on the railways, giving operators far more freedom.Commuters deserve better than finger-pointing and higher fares.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sajid javid non eu citizen migration loophole
story: Migration Watch said the number of multi-nationals exploiting inter-company transfers to bring in new recruits was up almost 25 per cent in the past decade.Inter-company transfers don’t count towards the cap on skilled non-EU workers – set at 20,700 a year.Migration Watch chair Andrew Green said: “Many people are asking why non-EU migration has not been reduced. Here is part of the answer.“Either the Government have taken their eye off the ball or they have been too heavily influenced by a small group of companies and have ignored their own.”Migration Watch said that since 1992, the number of ICTs (inter-company transfers) has increased eightfold. In 1997 the Home Office issued around 15,000 to workers and their families.This jumped to 47,000 in 2007 and 58,000 last year.Two types of ICTs can be issued – from long-term staff visas to permits for graduate trainees.Migration Watch’s blast comes just weeks after official figures revealed non-EU immigration pushed net migration to nearly 300,000 in the first full year since the Brexit referendum.Net migration from EU nations fell to just over 100,000 in 2017 – the lowest level in five years. title: mike ashley vows to save majority house of fraser
story: In his first interview since his Sports Direct firm bought the department store for £90million, the controversial owner of Newcastle United yesterday told The Sun he would try to keep 80 per cent of the 59 outlets open.So confident is he of achieving his target that he added: “In a year’s time you can hold my feet to the fire on that.”More than half were set for closure before Ashley, 53, took over last Friday — and he insisted there were brighter days ahead thanks to his ambitious vision to turn the 169-year-old chain into the Harrods of the high street.He explained: “In Harrods you get some exceptional services. What we would like to do is introduce a ‘concierge click and collect’ at House of Fraser.“When you go online and say you want to collect goods in-store, you should be able to book a time, book a changing room and book a stylist.“You get that kind of personal shopping service in a Harrods. There’s no reason why it couldn’t be rolled out nationally across House of Fraser.”Sports Direct, which already held an 11 per cent stake, bought House of Fraser outright just hours after it went into administration.It was left on the brink of collapse after the Chinese owner of toy store Hamleys pulled out of a £70million rescue deal.House of Fraser, which its new owner affectionately calls “HoF”, employs 17,000, including 11,500 in-store concession staff.Ashley, who is worth around £3billion, believes the key to securing its future is to introduce more luxury brands.He added that big-hitters such as Gucci, Prada, Stone Island and Mallet footwear were “the biggest thing missing” as House of Fraser ran into the red.Drawing on his experience with designer chain Flannels, which is owned by Sports Direct, he intends to stock House of Fraser with successful “cool brands of the moment”.He said: “We think the biggest and most important thing House of Fraser is missing is luxury brands. We think it will make a big difference.“It is not taking away from House of Fraser, but adding to it.“If you get the right product, it is not on the shelves for long.”Larger House of Fraser stores, such as the one in Birmingham, could see whole floors turned over to Sports Direct or Flannels, Ashley added.Among the stores that could be saved from closure is the Oxford Street flagship in London — if landlords and suppliers can be won over.Ashley admitted that landlords have been “battered and bruised” by a raft of retail tenants seeking rent reductions this year.In a message to them, he said: “Give us a chance and we will try to keep as many open as we can. We are here to get House of Fraser back to where it once was.”However, some analysts are sceptical that the colourful billionaire can pull it off.Independent retail analyst Nick Bubb warned: “It is far from clear if he really knows what he has taken on.”HOUSE OF FRASER lost its way but Ashley wants to take it upmarket with more luxury bestsellers, brands popular with younger customers and a personal shopper service.SPORTS DIRECT’s superstores are full of popular brands, including Lonsdale and Donnay. Dozens more outlets are planned as Ashley bids to turn it into the “Selfridges of sport”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy corbyn claims he does not remember laying wreath in tunisia
story: The Labour leader admitted he was at a 2014 ceremony for the Black September group behind the killing of 11 Israeli athletes and a policeman at the 1972 Munich Olympics.But he insisted he could not remember personally laying a wreath, adding: “I was present when it was laid. I don’t think I was actually involved in it.“I was there because I wanted to see a fitting memorial to everyone who has died in every terrorist incident everywhere.”Published pictures show Mr Corbyn clutching a large floral wreath during a visit to the Cemetery of the Martyrs of Palestine in Tunisia.Jewish Labour MP Luciana Berger yesterday said Mr Corbyn’s nit-picking over whether he actually laid a wreath was beyond the point.She said: “Being ‘present’ is the same as being involved.“When I attend a memorial my presence alone, whether I lay a wreath or not, demonstrates my association and support. There can also never be a ‘fitting memorial’ for terrorists. Where is the apology?”The row will only further inflame the rows within Labour over anti-semitism and alleged slurs likening Israelis to Nazis.Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu tweeted yesterday: “The laying of a wreath by Jeremy Corbyn on the graves of the terrorists who perpetrated the Munich massacre and his comparison of Israel to the Nazis deserves unequivocal condemnation from everyone – left, right and everything in between.”It sparked an extraordinary public spat as Mr Corbyn hit back by tweeting: “What deserves unequivocal condemnation is the killing of over 160 Palestinian protesters in Gaza by Israeli forces since March, including dozens of children.”Hard-left Labour MP Chris Williamson joined in, saying: “Benjamin Netanyahu leads a brutal rightwing apartheid regime. He has no moral authority whatsoever to criticise anyone, Let alone a man of peace.”Mr Corbyn’s admission that he was present at the wreath ceremony was made yesterday during a campaign visit to Walsall.It contradicted a statement from his own office denying he was there.The Labour press office also said those who claimed that Mr Corbyn was at the ceremony were misleading the widows of the murdered Israeli athletes, who have called on the Labour leader to apologise.Jewish Tory MP Andrew Percy said: “Jeremy Corbyn is a liar and has been found out. This is a sickening new low.”Labour Friends of Israel accused Mr Corbyn’s party of trying to “cover up” his visit.Tory chairman Brandon Lewis said Mr Corbyn’s changing accounts showed him to be “unfit for senior public office”.He said the Labour leader had “completely divorced” himself from the party’s tradition of fighting anti-Semitism.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brit henna tattoo scar friday night dinner quote
story: Beth Fitzimmons was with eight pals on the Greek island of Zante when they decided to have the words Shalom Jackie inked on them for a laugh last month.But the 18-year-old, from Southwell, Nottinghamshire, had an allergic reaction to an ingredient in the black henna, which can contain high levels of toxic chemical paraphenylenediamine (PPD).Doctors reckon shell be left with the words scarred on her forearm for at least six months.They chose the phrase from the popular Channel 4 comedy series because people on holiday kept shouting it and she and her friends found it amusing.She said the group were on their third night out of the holiday when they decided to get the five euro henna tattoo done - but it wasnt until around a week later that it began to itch and feel like a burn.Beth said: We were on a night out but I dont really drink so I was sober when I did it.It was done by a random family in the street. The mum and dad were doing them.We woke up the next day and thought it was hilarious. We sent pictures to our parents and and they were like that better not be permanent.It was absolutely fine until about eight days later then it was so itchy and it felt like it was burning.It was so red. It was all raised up. Now it looks a bit like eczema and is very dry.She went to a pharmacy when she got back to the UK and was told to go to a walk-in centre.Beth, who is taking a gap year after finishing her A-Levels this summer, added: I thought that was a bit extreme so I went to the doctor on the Monday.I said to them that I was probably overreacting but I needed to know if it was going to scar permanently because when I looked it up it said you needed to be treated for chemical burns.I was so worried it would scar me forever.The doctors told me Id had an allergic reaction to it and it would take about six months to go completely.Beth was prescribed a steroid cream and told that due to the chemicals in black henna also being used in hair dyes, she would no longer be able to dye her hair.She added: She [the pharmacist] was very firm on it because she said my body would start attacking whats in the hair dye and that I could actually die.That was the worst thing for me - not being able to dye my hair.Beth says everyone was shouting the phrase made popular by the character Jim on the show, which is about two brothers who return home for dinner with their parents every Friday night.Beth said: I love the show - its hilarious. Friday Night Dinner seems to be the thing that young people are obsessed with at the moment.It was everywhere in Zante. People would shout different lines back at each other.Warning others against the dangers, Beth said: I would 100 per cent say do not get black henna. If I would have known before I wouldnt have done it. It was a case of blind ignorance.

title: damian green ni hike 40s
story: The former Cabinet Minister made a fresh bid for middle-aged workers to pay hundreds more in tax every year in a newspaper interview.Asked how he’d fund a multi-billion shortfall in elderly care, he said: “In two ways: with an increase in national insurance for the over-40s, and the use of a small proportion of the housing wealth of the over-65s.”Mr Green added: “We have a system which assumes you retire in your early sixties and then live for a few years. title: tory new brexit plan next month
story: Arch-Brexiteers want to deliver a vision for an “alternative to Chequers” just days before a critical Tory party conference.Eurosceptics are incensed by the PM’s Chequers proposal - claiming a bid to stay in a single market for goods will tie the UK to EU rules for years to come.The plans are believed to have the support of Jacob Rees-Mogg, head of the Tory MPs ‘European Research Group’.Ex-Cabinet Minister Peter Lilley and John Redwood are looking at tariffs and trade options. No concessions.”The revelation came as Tory party bigwigs sparked backlash by urging local associations to back the PM’s Chequers plan on the doorstep.Conservative HQ was branded “moronic” by Eurosceptic MPs after asking regional branches to spend a small fortune on leaflets backing the PM’s soft Brexit plan.Maria Caulfield, who quit as vice-chair of the Tory Party over Chequers, said local officers and councillors were furious. title: the sun reader letters boris burka
story: But there has been a groundswell of support for BoJo from ordinary people, fed up at what they see as attacks on freedom of expression and the British way of life.This is what Sun readers have to say about the issue, and Brexit-backer Boris:BORIS Johnson has a dig at burka-wearing Muslims and our elite shake with fear. Don’t they know many thousands of people agree with him? Or do they chose to again ignore the people of this country? Any movement on Boris from the out-of-touch Government will cost them dear.SO Dominic Grieve has threatened to quit Parliament if Boris Johnson became PM. I can think of no better reason for wishing him success.BANG on Boris, about the burka. It being worn in public is scary for children who see it.FREEDOM of speech must not be compromised – and there can be no question of legal action being taken against Boris Johnson, it would be prejudiced by all the attacks on him.THIS week it has been especially hard to be a Muslim woman. Apparently I am not getting the joke, I’m over sensitive, bullied, oppressed, unintegrated, politically motivated, dividing Britain – this list goes on. Perhaps Boris Johnson’s Etonian education did not enable him to understand that in polite society it’s rude to comment with ridicule on the way people dress.ONE thing critics of Boris Johnson’s burka comment overlook is the impact of burka-wearers on those who are deaf and rely on seeing facial expressions, and lip-reading.THE do-gooders complaining about Boris are fanning the flames of hatred by highlighting issues that one wouldn’t really think about. Talk about “integration” appears to be one-sided and discriminatory towards the indigenous people. There is some equilibrium lacking in our “fair, just and equal” land of ours.WHILE I am not sure Boris used a good choice of words likening women in burkas to pillar boxes, he was right that we are frightened by what it represents. We must not destroy Boris, he is good for the people of this country, he cares. He must also be allowed to speak honestly, he has nothing to apologise for.LIGHTEN up, Boris spoke the thoughts of many millions of Brits. If making a gaffe was against the law, Prince Philip could have been banged up in the Tower of London on many occasions during the last 50 years. He wrote the book on it.Boris might have an agenda – what politician doesn’t? – but this mustn’t mean people don’t have a right to voice criticism. Face veils in public, and burkas, are not religious requirements and we must have the right to criticise the wearers.IF I was Boris Johnson, I would agree to attend the diversity training some have suggested . . . and then tear the training session to pieces.I SAW Ranvir Singh berating her guests on morning TV for daring to agree with Boris Johnson? I wonder what her bosses would say if she suggested that she presented her programme wearing a burka. I think we all know the answer to that.PHIL GROWDENNOTHING Theresa May says can be taken at face value. Not so long ago, she promised to stop the witch-hunt of British soldiers, who have seen action and survived in many parts of the world. However, the victimisation of our veterans continues unabated. They are now joined by Boris Johnson, who has frequently ignited the Prime Minister’s wrath and must therefore, be thrown to the wolves.A BUS company has apologised after a driver told a woman to remove her niqab. So would a bank apologise if a security guard asked a man to remove his ski mask?HOW would I stand as a Christian male finding a Muslim lady, dressed in a burka, having a heart attack? Would I be allowed to remove her veil to perform mouth-to-mouth?THE controversy surrounding Boris Johnson’s burka comments has reached ridiculous heights. Police conducting an investigation. Really?IF Theresa May had the guts to ban the burka like a lot of other countries, we might not be having this discussion about what Boris Johnson said.SOMETHING featureless with a rectangular hole in it can resemble a letter box, there’s probably one on your front door, go and have a look. It has also been known for the person inside to be a terrorist, not an innocent woman. Stop being so pathetic, have a sense of humour, act like adultsI READ about a motorcyclist at a filling station having to remove his crash helmet while a woman (who could have been a criminal’s getaway driver) filling up at the pump next to him was wearing a burka. Meanwhile Boris’s remarks are causing hysteria.I HAVE been visiting garden centres and supermarket car parks in my car, which is bedecked with Brexit stickers, asking many people their opinion on the Boris situation. For Boris, I find there is a great deal of love out there. For the Chequers “deal” there is none.IT’S true that Boris Johnson has used strong language but Muslim terrorists are doing far worse things than robbing banks, by committing terrorist atrocities. It would be a sad day when the Muslim community can’t take such a comment, especially when many Muslim women, in my view, do not want this clothing themselves.IT’S confirmed, lunatics are ruining the country. We have the enemy (EU) knocking art the door and all the idiots can find to discuss is Boris Johnson’s perfectly fair comment. If it wasn’t so serious it would be funny. Brexit should be top of the agenda.THERE are easily as many people who agree with BoJo’s comments as those who don’t. So why is it those who don’t will instigate an investigation, leaving those who do without a voice? Even senior Muslims and imams have said that the burka is not a requirement in Islam, so why is it we only tend to listen to those who are offended?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the last leg ally ross
story: You expect this reaction, obviously, from news organisations who have to fill endless blank hours with something during silly season.The really depressing thing, though, was that a late-night Channel 4 “comedy” show and its presenters were the most outraged of them all.I’m talking, of course, about The Last Leg which, for reasons that still escape me, genuinely fancies itself as one of television’s edgiest and funniest shows.It’s not, clearly. The Last Leg is a television safe space, the authentic voice of the PC establishment and as predictable as the sun rising in the morning.So you knew, long before Friday’s transmission, that they’d be targeting Boris, who is a thousand times funnier and edgier than anyone on this show, in his own way.Nearly a whole working week host Adam Hills and his two mates had to prepare some decent material as well, and this was the best three professional comedians could do.Alex Brooker: “The burka is an item of clothing worn by a human being, the other is a postbox, you f***ing idiot.”Adam Hills: “I’d much rather sit next to a person in burka than a p***k in a suit.”Josh Widdicombe: “Theresa May has only just realised Boris is a t**t, so she should apologise as well.”On and on it went, for 12 minutes and 54 seconds, a figure I mention because I’ve had the clock on this lot, and if you want to know exactly how much of a toss they really give about religious sensitivities then it’s best measured by the fact this series of The Last Leg has devoted just 65 hand-wringing seconds to the anti-Semitic poison infecting the Labour Party.It was crammed hurriedly into the previous episode, which was worth watching just to see Adam Hills describe Corbyn’s handling of this crisis as “a faux pas”, (which isn’t French for “shameful cluster-f***”) and the C4 audience react with evident discomfort because he’d drawn attention to the Labour leader’s failings and, therefore, broken one of comedy’s secret and golden rules.If you doubted these rules exist, incidentally, then ever the virtue-signalling fool, Adam Hills was good enough to spell them out for us on Friday.“Every religion should be open to ridicule . . . but you kind of need to be in the club.“Alex and I can make jokes about disabilities as we’re technically disabled.”Boris, he then explained, can’t make jokes about burkas, ’cos he’s “a white Etonian”, nor could comedy giant Rowan Atkinson defend him, as he was “a white man who lives in Oxford and drives an F1 car”.Even if we ignore the fact he’s assumed that all Muslims are black, something pretty staggering is going on here.For Mary Whitehouse, in all her pearl-clutching glory, never imagined anything quite as Draconian and controlling as this form of satirical Apartheid.Adam Hills has a point, though, when he uses the word “club”. That’s exactly what television comedy has become.A closed, left-wing shop where you don’t even bother joining the audience unless you follow the rigid “Tories and Brexit are evil” party line.This is not creating comedy, it’s policing it, and also the reason why applause has replaced laughter on all those Channel 4 and BBC news satires which have failed to realise there is only one simple rule to be observed when creating these shows: Make it funny, dumbo.I would suggest, at this point, Adam Hills gets off his moral high horse, for once, and gives this “funny” idea a go.But then I could also ask Boris to have a crack at anchoring the British women’s 4x100m relay team to gold at the next Olympics, wearing a burka, and I’d know there was only the remotest chance of one ever happening.Run Boris, run.MEANWHILE, back on Channel 4’s Meet The Drug Lords: Inside The Real Narcos, Jason “Foxy” Fox was with the Colombian navy this week and desperate for a look inside one of the incredible home-made submarines they’d confiscated from drug-smugglers.“Is it locked?”“Yes.”And there’ll be more Bafta-worthy action from Foxy and his forward-planning department this week, I’m sure.EVER since it discovered that Danny Dyer was the rightful heir to the English throne, Who Do You Think You Are? has been struggling to find a purpose, or indeed a celebrity, who could see the bigger picture.That special someone who would acknowledge history’s great events with more than a few “wows” and shrugs and not think their own career made all of their ancestors’ suffering worthwhile.Finally, last night, they found him.Judge Robert Rinder, who as well as having the best brain at ITV (Luna the Labrador off This Morning has the second best) also turns out to be a natural television journalist, telling the story of his maternal great-grandfather, Israel, and his beloved grandfather, Morris, simply, beautifully and without ever letting the details overwhelm him.The former fled revolutionary Latvia at the turn of the last century.The latter’s entire family was wiped out in Treblinka’s gas chambers.Yet he somehow survived the Buchen-wald, Theresienstadt and Schlieben concentration camps and made it to Britain, which offered him salvation, friendship, justice and, above all, a sense that “life is worth living” that has been passed down through eternally grateful generations.It’s a remarkable story, so if you missed it, try to catch tonight’s repeat (BBC1, 11.25pm).SCENES and characters the viewers are unlikely to forget in a hurry on the final episode of BBC2’s wonderful Travels In Trumpland With Ed Balls.First stop, the President’s Mar-a-Lago compound in Florida, where Ed spent the most uncomfortable night of his life, since Strictly, at a one-year-in-office party for Trump, with Toni Holt Kramer and a group of fans who were called The Trumpettes, but could well have been the provisional wing of The Golden Girls.If you thought they were a bit sinister, though, he was then off squirrel hunting in the forests of Georgia with two hillbillies who might not have been plucking banjos but they certainly had the mad cackling laughs and slightly unsettling line in hospitality.“Are you ready to be a man today, Ed?” asked one, as you began to wonder if he could escape with his dignity intact, let alone blend in with the local gene pool.Then he suddenly reappeared – and this was a masterstroke – wearing a Norwich City scarf.Scrub everything I ever said about Ed Balls.The man’s a diplomatic genius.Sent in by Rob Milner, East Yorkshire. Picture research: Alfie SnellingTHIS Morning, Wednesday:Gok Wan: “Coming up, Ninja nanas, in a minute, John Torode’s in the Lake District at 11.45, and we’ve got the return of the Hawaiian shirt at midday.“First, would you like to live ten years longer?”Ten years? Right now I’m ambivalent abOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: dad blames size nineteen feet for job woes as he cant find shoes big enough for job interviews
story: David Henderson, 39, can’t find smart black shoes that fit so he turns up to job interviews in his enormous white Adidas trainers — the only footwear he can get into.He says he’s been stuck on benefits for almost a decade as interviewers don’t take him seriously because of his get-up.And to add to his woes, cruel strangers mock him in the street with taunts like “clown shoes” and “Sideshow Bob”.The fed-up former security guard searched Scotland for a cobbler who would make him bespoke shoes but drew a blank.He extended his enquiries across the UK and found a London firm who could help.But to his horror they quoted him a price of £1,500 — far beyond his means as his Universal Credit payment leaves him just £40 to spend each month after bills.A pair of size 19 leather brogues could cost as much as an eye-watering £2,000.Now he’s going public with his problem in the hope it will help him find some decent shoes and get him off the dole.David, from Methil, Fife, said last night: “My feet have just got wider over time and doctors don’t know why.“Employers don’t believe me when I say I can’t buy black shoes but it’s impossible to find affordable ones in my size.“Some interviewers are bemused when I tell them why I’m not wearing black shoes.“Some are surprised and some are sympathetic. But I can tell some of them are thinking ‘are you for real?’“I feel like a bit of a tink turning up to job interviews wearing a tracksuit, T-shirt and trainers — but I would look ridiculous if I was wearing smart clothes and my big white trainers.”David added: “It’s been a total nightmare and very embarrassing. I feel like I have tried everywhere in Scotland but nobody does my size.“And I get people making fun of me when I’m at the bus stop or walking down the street people say ‘Wow. look at him. Are those boats on your feet?’. Others call me ‘banana feet’.It’s demoralising. I think I’d have a job if I had shoes. It brings me down and it’s pretty hurtful.“I just want to get back to work. I can’t be the only person in the UK with size 19 feet.”David, who is 6ft 2in tall and weighs in at 24 stone, has had big feet since he was youngster.When he left school he was a size 16. But he could find shoes that fitted him at the time and worked in retail, cleaning and security jobs through his 20s.But since then his feet have grown three sizes and are almost 12in long and 7in wide. David says he has been turned down by at least ten employers since he last worked.His worried girlfriend Annie Jones, 32, said she hopes he can resolve the situation and land a job.Annie said: “People laugh at him. They point at him and call him names. It’s mean when they call him “clown shoes” and it gets him down.I hope he can get back to work. It would mean a lot to him.”Do you have bigger feet? title: french mastiff helps owner deliver
story: The seven-year-old, ten stone pet chills in the ­passenger seat as owner Nicky Morris drops off parcels across London.And she thrills passersby who love to snap her casual “tradesman” pose.The 51-year-old said: Roxy, is not just a pet, she is a celebrity courier, who drives around London delivering parcels to people.She has been with us for seven years, since she was a puppy.Shes a dream to work with and it makes driving with her fun because of the constant attention.You can find her around central London - mostly posing for pictures.Roxy has got so famous that she has own Twitter and Instagram following.VOTE for your favourite Dog Friendly Car in The Sun Motor Awards 2018Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
